recordmixture 0.0.0.9000

    • quick start on recordmixutre

    quick start on recordmixutre

    demo.Rmd

    Linear Regression model

    We are considering the following linear regression model with mismatch error: \[ \mathbb{y} = \Pi\mathbb{X}\beta + \mathbb{\epsilon} \]

    The input of fit_mixture_gaussian function:

    • X : design matrix (collections of covariates in regression model)
      • Note that in order to fit a regression model with intercept term, one need to add rep(1, n) to X. Examples will be given in the following section.
    • y : reponse variable of regression model
    • g : density function of the marginal distribution of y
      • Under assumption in A Pseudo-Likelihood Approach to Linear Regression with Partially Shuffled Data, we have that \[y_i | \{\mathbb{x}_i, z_i = 0\} \sim f(y_i | \mathbb{x}_i), \qquad \qquad y_i | \{\mathbb{x}_i, z_i = 1\} \sim f_{y}(y_i), \]
      • We recommend using kernel density estimation function (density) in R for estimating g.
    • init : initial estimator for EM algorithm in mixture model approach. There are two options :
      • “LS” : Plain Lease square estimator which is given by \[ \beta = (X^{T} X)^{-1} X^{T} y \]
      • “robust” : Robust Linear Regression with M estimators and Huber’s method which is given by \[\beta = \min \sum^{n}_{i=1} \rho \left (\frac{y_{i} - \mathbb{x}_{i}\beta}{\sigma} \right ) \quad \rho = \begin{cases}x^2/2 & \text{if } |x| < c \\ c|x| - c^2/2 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\]
    • mp : match probabilities

    The following parameter are optional:

    • degration : indictor of whether degration factor will be applied for match probabilities. There are two options :
      • TRUE : \(\text{match probability} = \text{match probability}*(1 - \text{degration factor})\)
      • FALSE : degration factor will be not applied
    • df: ``degradation factor” on the match probabilities. The default value is 0.
    • logisRegMp : indictor of whether logistics regression for match probabilities will be used. There are two options :
      • TRUE : The following model will be applied \[\text{logit}(\text{match probability}) \sim \beta_{0} + g(\text{match probability})\beta\]
      • FALSE : logistics regression model will not be applied
    • link_function : link function (g) for logistics regression for match probabilities. This is applicable when logisRegMp is TRUE :
      • “identity” : \(g(x) = x\)
      • “logit” : \(g(x) = \log(\frac{x}{1 - x})\)
    • is_flagged : indicator variable for deterministic matches. Note that this is a logical vector. The default value is given by rep(FALSE, n).
      • TRUE : stands for observations are correctly matched
      • FALSE : stands for observations are mismatched

    The output of fit_mixture_gaussian function:

    Consider the following optizamation problem : \[ \max_{\beta \in \R^d, \, \sigma^2 > 0, \, \alpha \in [0,1] } \, \prod_{i = 1}^n f(y_i|\mathbb{x}_i), \] where \(f(y_i|\mathbb{x}_i)\) is mixture normal distribution given in in A Pseudo-Likelihood Approach to Linear Regression with Partially Shuffled Data

    • betahat : \(\beta\) regression parameter
    • sigmahat : \(\sigma\) noise of regression model
    • hshat : corrected match probabilities
    • conv : track of negative log Pseudo-Likelihood
    • family : family of distribution for regression model
    • like_ratios : likelihood ratios of \[ f_{y|x}(y_i|x_i) / f_y(y_i), i=1, \cdots ,n. \]
    • std_sandwich : sandwich estimator of standard error

    Examples without matching probabilities

    Generating Data from Linear Regression model 

    #######################################
set.seed(1234)
require(tictoc)
    ## Loading required package: tictoc
    require(MASS)
    ## Loading required package: MASS
    library(recordmixture)
n <- 10000
d <- 3
k_n <- 0.1
b <- 1
k <- round(n * k_n)
X <- matrix(rnorm(n*d), nrow = n, ncol = d)
##################without intercept
beta <- rnorm(d)
beta <- beta/ sqrt(sum(beta^2))
beta <- beta*b
sigma <- 1
y <- rnorm(n, X %*% beta, sigma)
yperm <- y
yperm[1:k] <- y[sample(1:k)]

######################################
kde_obj <- density(yperm)
dens <- approxfun(x = kde_obj$x, y = kde_obj$y, method = "linear")
tic()
res <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(X, yperm, dens, init = "LS", mp = rep(0,n))
toc()
    ## 0.406 sec elapsed
    ###########Mean Square Error##########
##########beta###############
sqrt(sum(res$betahat - beta)^2)
    ## [1] 0.0136344
    ##########sigma##############
abs(res$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.0002211395
    ##########hs##############
abs( (1 - res$hshat[1]) - k_n)
    ## [1] 0.002279398
    ##########likelihood ratios##
#res$like_ratios
##########standard error#####
res$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 2.243100 1.132359 1.192371 2.112753 2.353467
    ####with intercept (need to add intercept term to X)
beta <- rnorm(d+1)
beta <- beta/ sqrt(sum(beta^2))
beta <- beta*b
sigma <- 1
y <- rnorm(n, cbind(rep(1,n), X) %*% beta, sigma)
yperm <- y
yperm[1:k] <- y[sample(1:k)]

#################adding intercept term #####################
kde_obj <- density(yperm)
dens <- approxfun(x = kde_obj$x, y = kde_obj$y, method = "linear")
tic()
res <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(cbind(rep(1,n), X), yperm, dens, init = "robust", mp = rep(0,n))
toc()
    ## 0.557 sec elapsed
    ###########Mean Square Error##########
##########beta###############
sqrt(sum((c(res$betahat) - beta)^2))
    ## [1] 0.02288202
    ##########sigma##############
abs(res$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.01423058
    ##########hs##############
abs( (1 - res$hshat[1]) - k_n)
    ## [1] 0.0161376
    ##########likelihood ratios##
#res$like_ratios
##########standard error#####
res$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 1.184354 1.224687 1.820973 1.306230 1.983462 2.087430

    Examples with matching probabilities

    degradation factor model 

    n <- 1000
d <- 5
alpha <- 0.1

# simulate match probabilities
ps <- rbeta(n, 4.5, .5)
# ``degradation factor" on the match probs
gamma <- 1/4 
X <- matrix(rnorm(n*d), nrow = n, ncol = d)
beta <- rnorm(d)
beta <-  beta/ sqrt(sum(beta^2))
mustar <- X %*% beta
sigma <- 0.25
xi <- sigma * rnorm(n)
y <- drop(mustar + xi)
z <- 1 - (rbinom(n, prob = ps, size = 1) * rbinom(n, prob = 1-gamma, size = 1))
yperm <- y
for(i in 1:n){
   if(z[i] == 1) yperm[i] <- y[sample(setdiff(1:n, i),1)]
}
# obtain marginal distribution for y
kde_obj <- density(yperm)
dens <- approxfun(x = kde_obj$x, y = kde_obj$y, method = "linear")
mod1 <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(X, yperm, dens, init = "LS", mp = ps, degration = TRUE, df = gamma)

###########Mean Square Error##########
abs(mod1$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.003300359
    sqrt(sum((mod1$betahat - beta)^2))
    ## [1] 0.01451706
    ##########likelihood ratios###########
#res$like_ratios
#########standard error###############
mod1$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 0.3532345 0.3441559 0.3415905 0.3519718 0.3525168 0.2692466 0.6298966

    logistics Regression model 

    n <- 1000
d <- 5
alpha <- 0.1
ps <- rbeta(n, 4.5, .5)
X <- matrix(rnorm(n*d), nrow = n, ncol = d)
beta <- rnorm(d)
beta <-  beta/ sqrt(sum(beta^2))
mustar <- X %*% beta
sigma <- 0.25
xi <- sigma * rnorm(n)
y <- drop(mustar + xi)
gamma <- 1
gamma0 <- -1.5
logit_ps <- log(ps / (1 - ps))
eta <- gamma * logit_ps + gamma0
z <- 1 - rbinom(n, prob = plogis(eta), size = 1)
yperm <- y
for(i in 1:n){
   if(z[i] == 1) yperm[i] <- y[sample(setdiff(1:n, i),1)]
}
# obtain marginal distribution for y
kde_obj <- density(yperm)
dens <- approxfun(x = kde_obj$x, y = kde_obj$y, method = "linear")
mod2 <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(X, yperm, dens, init = "LS", mp = ps, logisRegMp = TRUE, link_function = "logit")
###########Mean Square Error##########
abs(mod2$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.01328484
    sqrt(sum((mod2$betahat - beta)^2))
    ## [1] 0.04005727
    ##########likelihood ratios###########
#mod2$like_ratios
#########standard error###############
mod2$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 0.3138974 0.3337379 0.3288645 0.3340359 0.3494230 0.3084765 7.4215453
## [8] 2.8512870

    incorporate flags for deterministic matches (assume we know that observations are correctly matched) 

    flagged <- sample(which(!z), 100) 
#-- those observations will also not be used in the logisitic model for match prob.
is_flagged <- logical(n)
is_flagged[flagged] <- TRUE
mod3 <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(X, yperm, dens, init = "LS", mp = ps, logisRegMp = TRUE, link_function = "logit", is_flagged = is_flagged)
###########Mean Square Error##########
abs(mod3$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.009663876
    sqrt(sum((mod3$betahat - beta)^2))
    ## [1] 0.04072971
    ##########likelihood ratios###########
#mod3$like_ratios
#########standard error##########
mod3$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 0.3538169 0.3611925 0.3627347 0.3609195 0.3782283 0.3327142 7.9544063
## [8] 2.9713143

    Generating deterministics matches indictor using given matching probabilities (i.e. We assuem that a match is correct if matching probabilities is 1) 

    flagged <- sample(which(!z), 100) 
#-- those observations will also not be used in the logisitic model for match prob.
ps[flagged] <- 1
is_flagged = (ps == 1)
mod3 <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(X, yperm, dens, init = "LS", mp = ps, logisRegMp = TRUE, link_function = "logit", is_flagged = is_flagged)

###########Mean Square Error##########
abs(mod3$sigmahat - sigma)
    ## [1] 0.01155529
    sqrt(sum((mod3$betahat - beta)^2))
    ## [1] 0.03892323
    ##########likelihood ratios###########
#mod3$like_ratios
#########standard error##########
mod3$std_sandwich
    ## [1] 0.3558278 0.3604305 0.3705427 0.3752900 0.3836389 0.3353624 7.7785475
## [8] 2.9250809

    Real Data Example (Need to be ran locally with data in r)

    Here is an example of real data analysis which was given in the Workshop : Linear Regression With Linked Data. The regression model is given below \[ \begin{split} \texttt{air.temp} & = \beta_0 + \beta_{\texttt{zon}} \cdot \texttt{zon} + \beta_{\texttt{mer}} \cdot \texttt{mer} + \\ &\;\qquad + \beta_{\texttt{humidity}} \cdot \texttt{humidity} + \beta_{\texttt{s.s.temp}} \cdot \texttt{s.s.temp} + \epsilon. \end{split} \]

    elnino <- read.csv("~/elnino-large/elnino.csv", header = TRUE)
elnino_merged <- read.csv("~/elnino-large/elnino-merged.csv", header = TRUE)

lm_oracle <- lm(air.temp ~ s.s.temp + zon.winds + mer.winds + humidity, data = elnino)
lmmerged_naive <- lm(air.temp ~ s.s.temp + zon.winds + mer.winds + humidity, data = elnino_merged)

    Here we are referring to regression model built without any mismatch as oracle model and regression model built with mismatch as naive model. Here is a plot of true response vs mismatched response.

    plot(elnino$air.temp, elnino_merged$air.temp, xlab = "true", ylab = "mismatched")

    Since in this regression model, we are assuming an intercept term. So we need to center the design matrix and response variable.

    X <- model.matrix(lmmerged_naive)
X <- X[,!(colnames(X) %in% "(Intercept)")]
y <- model.extract(lmmerged_naive$model, "response")

    Then we perform the mixture approach on centered X and y, then we have that ## Add intercept term to design matrix

    kde_obj <- density(y)
dens <- approxfun(x = kde_obj$x, y = kde_obj$y, method = "linear")
n = nrow(X)
res <- fit_mixture_Gaussian(cbind(rep(1,n), X), y, dens, init = "robust", mp =  rep(0,n))
sqrt(sum((res$betahat - coef(lm_oracle))^2))
#########standard error##########
#sqrt(diag(res$sandwich))
